facts.text: C. I. Emden (appellant) was convicted under section 161 of the Indian Penal Code and section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: convicted under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code and under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act 2 of 1947  hereinafter called the Act . The case against him was that he had accepted a bribe of Rs. 375 from Sarat Chandra Shukla on January 8, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant accepted a bribe of Rs. 375 from Sarat Chandra Shukla on January 8, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The case against him was that he had accepted a bribe of Rs. 375 from Sarat Chandra Shukla on January 8, 1953. The appellant was a Loco Foreman at Alambagh Loco Shed, and Shukla had secured a contract at the same place for the removal of cinders

facts.text: Appellant was Loco Foreman at Alambagh Loco Shed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a Loco Foreman at Alambagh Loco Shed, and Shukla had secured a contract at the same place for the removal of cinders 76 from ash pits and for loading coal.

facts.text: Shukla secured a contract at Alambagh Loco Shed for removal of cinders from ash pits and loading coal in June 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and Shukla had secured a contract at the same place for the removal of cinders 76 from ash pits and for loading coal. This contract had been given to Shukla in June 1952.

facts.text: Appellant demanded Rs. 400 per month from Shukla to allow peaceful execution of contract without harassment.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that the appellant demanded from Shukla Rs. 400 per month in order that Shukla may be allowed to carry out his contract peacefully without any harassment.

facts.text: Appellant told Shukla he received monthly payment from previous contractor Ram Ratan.

anchor.surface_text: Shukla was told by the appellant that he had been receiving a monthly payment from Ram Ratan who had held a similar contract before him and that it would be to his interest to agree to pay the bribe.

facts.text: Shukla refused to pay the bribe, leading to hostile acts by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Shukla, however, refused to accede to this request and that led to many hostile acts on the part of the appellant.

facts.text: On January 3, 1953, appellant again demanded monthly bribe from Shukla.

anchor.surface_text: On January 3, 1953, the appellant again asked Shukla to pay him the monthly bribe as already suggested Shukla then requested him to reduce the demand on the ground that the contract given to him was for a much lesser amount

facts.text: Appellant agreed to accept Rs. 375 as reduced bribe amount.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant thereupon agreed to accept Rs. 375. Shukla had no money at the time and so he asked for time to make the necessary arrangement.

facts.text: Agreement to pay Rs. 375 on January 8, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement then was that Shukla would pay the money to the appellant on January 8, 1953. Meanwhile Shukla approached the Deputy Superintendent, of Police, Corruption Branch, and gave him information about the illegal demand made by the appellant.

facts.text: Shukla informed Deputy Superintendent of Police, Corruption Branch, about the demand.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile Shukla approached the Deputy Superintendent, of Police, Corruption Branch, and gave him information about the illegal demand made by the appellant. Shuklas statement was then recorded before a magistrate and it was decided to lay a trap.

facts.text: Shukla's statement recorded before a magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: Shuklas statement was then recorded before a magistrate and it was decided to lay a trap. Accordingly, a party consisting of Shukla, the magistrate, the Deputy Superintendent of Police and some other persons went to the Loco Yard.

facts.text: Trap laid: party including Shukla, magistrate, DSP went to Loco Yard.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, a party consisting of Shukla, the magistrate, the Deputy Superintendent of Police and some other persons went to the Loco Yard. Shukla and Sada Shiv proceeded inside the Yard while the rest of the party stood at the gate.

facts.text: Shukla met appellant inside yard, informed brought money; appellant went out to secluded place.

anchor.surface_text: Shukla then met the appellant and informed him that he had brought the money he was told that the appellant would go out to the Yard and accept the money. At about 3 p.m. the appellant went out to the Yard and, after making a round, came to the place which was comparatively secluded.

facts.text: At about 3 p.m. on January 8, 1953, Shukla gave appellant bundle of marked currency notes of Rs. 375.

anchor.surface_text: He then asked Shukla to pay the money and Shukla gave him a bundle containing the marked currency notes of the value of Rs. 375. A signal was then made by Shukla and the raiding party immediately arrived on the scene.

facts.text: Raiding party arrived after signal; magistrate asked appellant to produce money; appellant handed over currency notes from pocket.

anchor.surface_text: A signal was then made by Shukla and the raiding party immediately arrived on the scene. The magistrate disclosed his identity to the appellant and asked him to produce the amount paid to him by Shukla. The appellant then took out the currency notes from his pocket and handed them over to the magistrate.

facts.text: Appellant admitted receiving Rs. 375 from Shukla but claimed it was a loan for children's clothing expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied the charge. He admitted that he had received Rs. 375 from Shukla but his case was that at his request Shukla had advanced the said amount to him by way of loan for meeting the expenses of the clothing of his children who were studying in school.

facts.text: Appellant alleged he requested Kishan Chand for loan of Rs. 500; Shukla offered to advance Rs. 375 knowing his need.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleged that since he had been in need of money he had requested Kishan Chand to arrange for a loan of Rs. 500 but knowing about his need Shukla offered to advance him the loan, and it was as such loan that Shukla paid him Rs. 375 and the appellant accepted the said amount.

facts.text: Special Judge, Anti-corruption, Lucknow convicted appellant on October 31, 1955 in Criminal Case No. 2/3/32/45 of 1953-55.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 11, 1957, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench , Lucknow, in Criminal Appeal No. 515 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated October 31, 1955, of the Special Judge, Anti-corruption, Lucknow, in Criminal Case No. 2/3/32/45 of 1953-55.

facts.text: Special Judge sentenced appellant to 1 year RI and Rs.500 fine under s.161 IPC, 2 years RI under s.5 PCA, concurrent.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the learned judge convicted the appellant of both the offences charged and sentenced him to suffer one years rigorous imprisonment and to pay a fine of Rs. 500 under s. 161 of the Code and two years rigorous imprisonment under s. 5 of the Act. Both the sentences were ordered to run concurrently.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench, by judgment dated July 11, 1957 in Criminal Appeal No. 515 of 1955, confirmed conviction, reduced s.5 sentence to 1 year RI.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 68 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 11, 1957, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench , Lucknow, in Criminal Appeal No. 515 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated October 31, 1955, of the Special Judge, Anti-corruption, Lucknow, in Criminal Case No. 2/3/32/45 of 1953-55.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave: Criminal Appeal No. 68 of 1958, judgment December 15, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 68 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 11, 1957, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench , Lucknow, in Criminal Appeal No. 515 of 1955,

facts.text: Special Judge believed Shukla's evidence, found it corroborated, rejected defense story as improbable.

anchor.surface_text: Both the prosecution and the defence led evidence to support their respective versions. The learned special judge who tried the case believed the evidence given by Shukla, held that it was sufficiently corroborated, and found that the defence story was improbable and untrue.

facts.text: Special Judge raised presumption under s.4 PCA, not rebutted by defense.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judge also held that on the evidence led before him the presumption under s. 4 of the Act had to be raised and that the said presumption had not been rebutted by the evidence led by the defence.

facts.text: High Court held presumption under s.4 raised and not rebutted, did not consider prosecution evidence apart from presumption.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court saw no reason to interfere with the order under appeal because it held that, on the facts of the case, a statutory presumption under s. 4 had to be raised and that the said presumption had not been rebutted by the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.4(1) PCA constitutional, not violating Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, no hesitation in holding that the challenge to the vires of s. 4 1  on the ground that it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution must fail.

facts.text: Appellant had bank balance of Rs.1,600 at material time, salary Rs.600 per month.

anchor.surface_text: It has found that at the material time the appellant was in possession of a bank balance of Rs. 1,600 and that his salary was about Rs. 600 per month.

facts.text: Appellant's children went to school in March, no immediate pressure for clothing.

anchor.surface_text: Besides his children for whose clothing he claims to have borrowed money had to go to school in March and there was no immediate pressure for preparing their clothes.

facts.text: Supreme Court disbelieved defense witnesses Kishan Chand and Ram Ratan, found defense explanation improbable.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has examined this evidence and has disbelieved it. It has found that Kishan Chand is an interested witness and that the story deposed to by him is highly improbable.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court finding that defense explanation unreasonable, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in discarding the explanation given by the appellant as wholly unsatisfactory and unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 68 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

issues.text: whether s. 4(1) of the Act which requires a presumption to be raised against an accused person is unconstitutional and ultra vires as it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been placed before a Constitution Bench because one of the points which the appellant raises for our decision is that s. 4 1  of the Act which requires a presumption to be raised against an accused person is unconstitutional and ultra vires as it violates the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: When does the statutory presumption fall to be raised under s. 4(1), and what is the content of the said presumption?

anchor.surface_text: construting s. 4 1 . When does the statutory presumption fall to be raised, and what is the content of the said presumption? Mr. Anthony contends that the statutory presumpion cannot be raised merely on proof of the fact that the appellant had received Rs. 375 from Shukla in order to justify the raising of the statutory presumption it must also be shown by the prosecution that the amount was paid and accepted as by way of bribe.

issues.text: whether the onus of proof on the accused to prove the contrary under s. 4(1) is less heavy than that on the prosecution (preponderance of probabilities rather than beyond reasonable doubt)

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged by Mr. Anthony that even if the statutory presumption is raised against the appellant, in deciding the question as to whether the contrary is proved within the meaning of s. 4 1  it must be borne in mind that the onus of proof on the appellant is not as heavy as it is on the prosecution in a criminal trial. Let us first consider when the presumption can be raised under s. 4 1 .

arguments.claim: s. 4(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 is unconstitutional and ultra vires as it violates Article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been placed before a Constitution Bench because one of the points which the appellant raises for our decision is that s. 4 1  of the Act which requires a presumption to be raised against an accused person is unconstitutional and ultra vires as it violates the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: but it. In the result the companyviction of the appellant was companyfirmed, the sentence passed against him under s. 161 was maintained but the sente

arguments.court_reasoning: Art. 14 permits reasonable classification based on intelligible differentia with rational relation to legislative object of eradicating corruption among public servants

arguments.claim: s. 4(1) does not violate Article 14 as it is based on reasonable classification of public servants accused of bribery with rational nexus to object of preventing corruption

anchor.surface_text: The scope and effect of the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 14 has been considered by this Court on several occasions as a result of the decisions of this Court it is well established that Art. 14 does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation but it forbids class legislation but if it appears that the impugned legislation is based on a reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia and that the said differentia have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by it, its validity cannot be successfully challenged under Art. 14 Vide Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar .

arguments.claim: statutory presumption under s.4(1) cannot be raised merely on proof of receipt of Rs.375; prosecution must also prove the amount was paid and accepted as bribe

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the question of construing s. 4 1 . When does the statutory presumption fall to be raised, and what is the content of the said presumption? Mr. Anthony contends that the statutory presumpion cannot be raised merely on proof of the fact that the appellant had received Rs. 375 from Shukla in order to justify the raising of the statutory presumption it must also be shown by the prosecution that the amount was paid and accepted as by way of bribe.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: o enact s. 4 1  with a view to require the raising of the statutory presumption as soon as the companydition precedent prescribed by it in that behalf

arguments.court_reasoning: word 'gratification' means any satisfaction other than legal remuneration; otherwise superfluous and inconsistent with 'valuable thing' clause for s.165

arguments.claim: 'gratification' in s.4(1) should be construed in literal dictionary meaning as satisfaction of appetite or desire; presumption arises on proof of receipt other than legal remuneration

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand Mr. Mathur, for the State, argues that the word gratification should be construed in its literal dictionary meaning and as such it means satisfaction of appetite or desire that is to say the presumption can be raised whenever it is shown that the accused has received satisfaction either of his desire or appetite.

arguments.court_reasoning: fits scheme of section, consistent with valuable thing clause, avoids superfluity

arguments.claim: presumption under s.4(1) arises upon proof that accused accepted any gratification other than legal remuneration or valuable thing, without need to prove corrupt intent

anchor.surface_text: What the prosecution has to prove before asking the court to raise a presumption against an accused person is that the accused person has received a gratification other than legal remuneration if it is shown, as in the present case it has been shown, that the accused received the stated amount and that the said amount was not legal remuneration then the condition prescribed by the section is satisfied.

arguments.claim: even if presumption raised, onus on accused under s.4(1) is lighter than prosecution's (preponderance of probabilities suffices to rebut)

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged by Mr. Anthony that even if the statutory presumption is raised against the appellant, in deciding the question as to whether the contrary is proved within the meaning of s. 4 1  it must be borne in mind that the onus of proof on the appellant is not as heavy as it is on the prosecution in a criminal trial.

arguments.court_reasoning: assumed in favor of appellant that reasonable probability suffices but defense explanation still not probable

arguments.claim: onus on accused to rebut presumption under s.4(1) is same as prosecution: 'proved' per Evidence Act s.3 requires belief or prudent man probability

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the State it is urged by Mr. Mathur that in construing the effect of the clause unless the contrary is proved we must necessarily refer to the definition of the word proved prescribed by s. 3 of the Evidence Act. A fact is said to be proved when, after considering the matter before it, the Court either believes it to exist or considers its existence so probable that a prudent man ought under the circumstances of the particular case to act on the supposition that it exists.

arguments.court_reasoning: not necessary to decide as even assuming lighter onus, explanation fails

He admitted that he had received Rs. 375 from Shukla but his case was that at his request Shukla had advanced the said amount to him by way of loan for meeting the expenses of the clothing of his children who were studying in school. The appellant alleged that since he had been in need of money he had requested Kishan Chand to arrange for a loan of Rs. 500 but knowing about his need Shukla offered to advance him the loan, and it was as such loan that Shukla paid him Rs. 375 and the appellant accepted the said amount.

The learned judge also held that on the evidence led before him the presumption under s. 4 of the Act had to be raised and that the said presumption had not been rebutted by the evidence led by the defence.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court and Supreme Court concur on improbability of defense

arguments.claim: presumption under s.4 raised on facts and not rebutted by appellant

anchor.surface_text: The High Court saw no reason to interfere with the order under appeal because it held that, on the facts of the case, a statutory presumption under s. 4 had to be raised and that the said presumption had not been rebutted by the appellant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: can be numberdoubt that the basis adopted by the Legislature in classifying one class of public servants who are brought within the mischief of s. 4 1

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court confirms presumption properly raised but examines evidence independently

holdings.text: The challenge to the vires of s. 4(1) on the ground that it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution must fail.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, no hesitation in holding that the challenge to the vires of s. 4 1  on the ground that it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution must fail. Incidentally, we may refer to the decision of this Court in A. S. Krishna v. The State of Madras  2  in which a similar challenge to the vires of a statutory presumption required to be raised under s. 4 2  of the Madras Prohibition Act, 10 of 1937, has been repelled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 14 permits reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia (public servants accused of bribery) with rational relation to object of eradicating corruption; follows Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia precedent.

holdings.text: The statutory presumption under s. 4(1) falls to be raised upon proof that the accused accepted any gratification other than legal remuneration or any valuable thing, without proof that it was by way of bribe.

anchor.surface_text: What the prosecution has to prove before asking the court to raise a presumption against an accused person is that the accused person has received a gratification other than legal remuneration if it is shown, as in the present case it has been shown, that the accused received the stated amount and that the said amount was not legal remuneration then the condition prescribed by the section is satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'gratification' as any satisfaction other than legal remuneration fits scheme of section, avoids superfluity, consistent with 'valuable thing' clause for s.165; rejects need to prove corrupt intent upfront.

holdings.text: In the present case, the High Court was justified in raising the presumption against the appellant because it is admitted that he received Rs. 375 from Shukla which was other than legal remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that in the present appeal the High Court was justified in raising the presumption against the appellant because it is admitted by him that he received Rs. 375 from Shukla and that the amount thus received by him was other than legal remuneration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.4(1) to admitted facts of receipt of money not legal remuneration.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether the onus on the accused under s.4(1) is lighter than on prosecution; even assuming explanation reasonably probable suffices to rebut, appellant's explanation fails.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think it necessary to decide this point in the present appeal. We are prepared to assume in favour of the appellant that even if the explanation given by him is a reasonably probable one the presumption raised against him can be said to be rebutted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes arguendo lighter onus (preponderance of probability per precedents like Carr-Briant) but finds explanation improbable anyway.

holdings.text: The explanation given by the appellant that Rs.375 was a loan is wholly unsatisfactory and unreasonable; presumption not rebutted.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in discarding the explanation given by the appellant as wholly unsatisfactory and unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defense witnesses discredited as interested/improbable; appellant had Rs.1600 bank balance, Rs.600 salary, no urgent clothing need (school in March), unlikely loan from hostile Shukla.

precedents.citation: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar  1

anchor.surface_text: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar  1 . In the present case there can be nodoubt that the basis adopted by the Legislature in classifying one class of public servants who are brought within the mischief of s. 4 1  is a perfectly rational basis.

precedents.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v Shri Justice SR Tendolkar
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 14 does not forbid reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia with rational relation to the object sought to be achieved

precedents.citation: A. S. Krishna v. The State of Madras  2

anchor.surface_text: A. S. Krishna v. The State of Madras  2  in which a similar challenge to the vires of a statutory presumption required to be raised under s. 4 2  of the Madras Prohibition Act, 10 of 1937, has been repelled.

precedents.case_name: AS Krishna v State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Similar challenge to vires of statutory presumption repelled

anchor.surface_text: The State v. Abhey Singh  1  as well as the decision of the Bombay High Court in the State v. Pandurang Laxman Parab  2 . On the other hand Mr. Mathur, for the State, argues that the word gratification should be construed in its literal dictionary meaning

precedents.cited_proposition: Gratification in s.4(1) requires proof that money was received by way of bribe

precedents.citation: the State v. Pandurang Laxman Parab  2

anchor.surface_text: the State v. Pandurang Laxman Parab  2 . On the other hand Mr. Mathur, for the State, argues that the word gratification should be construed in its literal dictionary meaning and as such it means satisfaction of appetite or desire that is to say the presumption can be raised whenever it is shown that the accused has received satisfaction either of his desire or appetite.

precedents.cited_proposition: Gratification in s.4(1) requires proof that money was received by way of bribe

anchor.surface_text: State v. Pundlik Bhikaji Ahire  3  and by the Allahabad High Court in Promod Chander Shekhar v. Rex  4 . Paragraph 3 of s. 161 of the Code provides that the word gratification is not restricted to pecuniary gratification or to gratifications estimable in money.

precedents.cited_proposition: Word gratification should be construed in literal meaning, not confined to bribe

anchor.surface_text: Promod Chander Shekhar v. Rex  4 . Paragraph 3 of s. 161 of the Code provides that the word gratification is not restricted to pecuniary gratification or to gratifications estimable in money. Therefore gratification mentioned in s. 4 1  cannot be confined only to payment of money.

precedents.cited_proposition: Word gratification should be construed in literal meaning, not confined to bribe

precedents.citation: Otto George Gfeller v. The King 1

anchor.surface_text: Otto George Gfeller v. The King 1  the Privy Council was dealing with the case where the prosecution had established that the accused were in possession of goods recently stolen and the point which arose for decision was how the explanation given by the accused about his possession of the said goods would or should be considered by the jury.

precedents.case_name: Otto George Gfeller v The King
precedents.cited_proposition: Accused does not have to prove his story beyond reasonable doubt; if explanation breaks down, conviction possible

anchor.surface_text: Rex v. Carr Briant  1  where it has been observed that in any case where either by statute or at common law some matter is presumed against an accused, unless the contrary is -proved the jury should be directed that it is for them to decide whether the contrary is proved, that the burden of proof required is less than that required at the hands of the prosecution in proving the case beyond a reasonable doubt,

precedents.cited_proposition: Burden on accused to rebut presumption is less than proof beyond reasonable doubt; probability suffices

anchor.surface_text: Also vide Regina v. Dunbar  2  . It is on the strength of these decisions that Mr. Anthony contends that in deciding whether the contrary has been proved or not under s. 4 1  the High Court should not have applied the same test as has to be applied in dealing with the prosecution case.

precedents.cited_proposition: Onus on accused to rebut presumption is satisfied by evidence of probability

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in discarding the explanation given by the appellant as wholly unsatisfactory and unreasonable. That being so it is really number necessary in the present appeal to decide the question about the nature of the onus of proof cast upon the accused by s. 4 1  after the statutory presumption is raised against him.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment upheld; appellant's explanation discarded as unsatisfactory; presumption not rebutted; constitutional challenge to s.4(1) rejected

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, no hesitation in holding that the challenge to the vires of s. 4 1  on the ground that it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution must fail. Incidentally, we may refer to the decision of this Court in A. S. Krishna v. The State of Madras  2  in which a similar challenge to the vires of a statutory presumption required to be raised under s. 4 2  of the Madras Prohibition Act, 10 of 1937, has been repelled.

Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in discarding the explanation given by the appellant as wholly unsatisfactory and unreasonable. That being so it is really number necessary in the present appeal to decide the question about the nature of the onus of proof cast upon the accused by s. 4 1  after the statutory presumption is raised against him.

anchor.surface_text: What the prosecution has to prove before asking the court to raise a presumption against an accused person is that the accused person has received a gratification other than legal remuneration if it is shown, as in the present case it has been shown, that the accused received the stated amount and that the said amount was not legal remuneration then the condition prescribed by the section is satisfied.

Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in discarding the explanation given by the appellant as wholly unsatisfactory and unreasonable. That being so it is really number necessary in the present appeal to decide the question about the nature of the onus of proof cast upon the accused by s. 4 1  after the statutory presumption is raised against him.

edges.explanation: Justification of presumption against appellant supports conviction under section 5(2) PCA.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that in the present appeal the High Court was justified in raising the presumption against the appellant because it is admitted by him that he received Rs. 375 from Shukla and that the amount thus received by him was other than legal remuneration.

Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in discarding the explanation given by the appellant as wholly unsatisfactory and unreasonable. That being so it is really number necessary in the present appeal to decide the question about the nature of the onus of proof cast upon the accused by s. 4 1  after the statutory presumption is raised against him.

edges.explanation: The holding applies and thereby supports the operation of Section 4 Evidence Act by evaluating evidence against the presumption under s.4(1).

anchor.surface_text: We do not think it necessary to decide this point in the present appeal. We are prepared to assume in favour of the appellant that even if the explanation given by him is a reasonably probable one the presumption raised against him can be said to be rebutted.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 follows the principle in precedent p8 by assuming that an explanation that is reasonably probable suffices to rebut the presumption, echoing p8's statement that probability suffices for the accused's burden.
